questions.text: 1. The time between the receipt of the infectious agent into the host's body and the period of maximum infectivity is known as:
questions.solution:
The time between the receipt of the infectious agent into the host's body and the period of maximum infectivity is known as the generation time. It is not the same as the incubation period because the time of maximum communicability may precede or follow the incubation period. 

Other Options: 

Option B: The incubation period refers to the time between invasion by an infectious agent and the appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease. The median incubation period refers to the time between exposure to a pathogen and the onset of symptoms in 50% of cases

Option C: Communicable period is the time during which an infectious agent may be transferred directly or indirectly from an infected individual to another individual.

Option D: Serial interval is the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case. The term serial interval is used in an outbreak of disease.

Pearl PM0361: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.



Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: 2. As per the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation programme, what dose of IFA tablets is provided to children in the 10-19 year age group?

choices.text: 100 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid
60 mg elemental iron and 50 mcg folic acid
60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid
100 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid

questions.solution:
As per the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation programme, IFA tablets containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid are provided to children in the 10-19 year age group.

Earlier, the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS) programme, launched in 2012, was targeted mainly at adolescents in the 10–19 year age group. Under this, they were provided one IFA tablet containing 100 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid once weekly, along with biannual deworming with Albendazole. However, since 2018, WIFS has been brought under the Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) strategy as part of the 6x6x6 initiative.

Under AMB, iron and folic acid supplementation has been expanded to cover ages from 6 months of age up to 49 years, including children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant and lactating women. Under AMB, the prophylactic IFA supplementation for adolescents (10–19 years) has been revised to one blue-coloured tablet per week containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 µg folic acid. 

The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare had launched the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS) Programme to reduce the prevalence and severity of anaemia in the adolescent population (10-19 years). The target groups included school-going adolescent girls and boys in 6th to 12th class enrolled in government/government-aided/municipal schools and out-of-school adolescent girls.

The key interventions included:

* Administration of supervised Weekly Iron-folic Acid Supplements using a fixed day approach.

* Screening of target groups for moderate/severe anaemia and referring these cases to an appropriate health facility.

* Biannual deworming (Albendazole 400mg), six months apart, for control of helminthic infestation.

* Information and counselling for improving dietary intake and for taking actions for prevention of intestinal worm infestation.

Pearl PM2210: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Age group Dose Frequency Tablet Color
Children
6-59 months of age

 

1 mL iron and folic acid syrup

Each mL contains 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg of folic acid

Bi-weekly

  Syrup
Children
5-9 years of age

 

1 Iron and folic acid tablet

45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated

 Weekly   Pink

School-going adolescent girls and Boys
10-19 years of age

Out-of-school adolescent girls
10-19 years of age

 

1 iron and folic acid tablet

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid, 

Sugar-coated

 Weekly   Blue

Women of reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating)
20-49 years

(Under Mission Parivar Vikas)

 

1 iron and folic acid tablet

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid, 

Sugar-coated 

 Weekly   Red
Pregnant Women and Lactating Mothers
of 0-6 months child

 

1 iron and folic acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy is continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days). It should also be continued for 180 days post-partum.

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated and red color

 Daily  Red 


Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: 3. Which statistical test can be used to compare the mean haemoglobin values of two independent groups?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the unpaired t-test would be used to compare the mean haemoglobin values of two independent groups when the data is normally distributed. Since the study involves independent groups and a continuous variable (mean haemoglobin), the unpaired t-test is the most appropriate choice.

Tests of significance are used to check for a significant association between two or more variables. Examples are the Student t-test, Paired t-test, Chi-square test, ANOVA, and Fischer-exact test.

An unpaired t-test is a parametric statistical test determining whether a statistically significant difference exists between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups.



Other options:

Option A: Chi-square test is used to test whether the difference between the two proportions is significant. It is used for categorical data and is not suitable for comparing means of continuous variables. It can also be used when more than two groups are to be compared. 

Option C: Paired t-test is a parametric test and analyses the mean difference in a paired sample, like pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare means across three or more groups, not just two.

Pearl PM1104: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

* See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?

* If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.

* If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .

* If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

* If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

* Unpaired t tests

* Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.

* It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.

* Paired t tests

* "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"

* So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 

* Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.

* It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.

* It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.

* T scores 

* The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.

* The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

* The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

* The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

* It is a test of proportions and associations.

* A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.

* If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: 4. Few mosquito larvae are seen. In one of them, palmate hair is seen on the abdomen, it has no siphon tube, and it is seen lying parallel to the surface of water. Which species does it belong to?
questions.solution:
The larva described belongs to the species Anopheles, which can be identified as it lies parallel to the undersurface of water. It doesn't have a siphon tube in its larval stage, but has palmate hairs on abdominal segments. 

Anopheles eggs are laid singly and are boat-shaped with lateral floats. The larvae rest parallel to the water surface, have no siphon tube, and possess palmate hairs on the abdominal segments. The pupae have a broad, short siphon tube. Adults at rest are inclined at an angle to the surface, have spotted wings, and long palpi in both sexes. The Anopheles mosquitoes are vectors for malaria.

On the other hand, Aedes, Culex and Mansonia larvae (Option B, C, and D) are suspended with the head downwards at an angle to the water surface. They lack palmate hairs and have a siphon tube. Eggs are oval-shaped without lateral floats. Culex and Mansonia lay eggs in clusters or rafts, while Aedes lays them singly but without lateral floats. Adults also differ in resting posture and have unspotted wings.



Pearl PM1668: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

* Mosquitoes are global in distribution

* The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia

* Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters

* The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days

* Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen

* The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 


 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.



 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.



Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: 5. In 'De facto' method of census data collection, information is collected based on which of the following?

choices.text: Location at the time of enumeration

questions.solution:
In 'De facto' method of census data collection, information is collected based on location at the time of enumeration. 

A census is defined by the United Nations as the total process of collecting, compiling and publishing demographic, economic and social data pertaining at a specified time to all persons in a country. There are two methods of census in India:

De facto method - In this method, a date will be fixed for the census of the whole country. Usually, such an operation is carried out during the night, known as the census night. Enumerators count the people on this night wherever they are found, based on location at the time of enumeration. The De facto concept is equivalent to taking a snapshot of the population at a reference time point. Since the enumeration is rounded off in a day, it is also called the date system or one-night enumeration system. The De facto method of census was carried out till 1931.

De jure Method - In this method, every individual in a particular area is personally counted, and the requisite information is obtained. The temporary residents are enumerated at their permanent place of residence. All persons who usually live in a country/territory at a particular reference time-point (usually taken as the middle of a year)  will be counted as the population of the country/territory. The enumeration work is prolonged for two to three weeks, which is known as the enumeration period. This method is also known as the period system, because census taking is confined to a particular period and not confined to a particular date. India's census is presently based on the De jure method.

questions.text: 6. Which of the vaccines given below would you use for the immunisation clinic in your hospital?
questions.solution:
From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.

Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color and thus cannot be used. Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square compared to the outer circle.

Pearl PM0698: Vaccine Vial Monitors

* Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.

* It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

* If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.



* Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.

* The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.

* VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

Pearl PM0697: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: 7. A district survey shows that screening of breast cancer increases the 5-year survival rate. However, autopsy studies showed no real change in mortality. Which type of bias is seen here?
questions.solution:
This scenario describes a situation where screening seems to improve survival time, but in reality, it only detects the disease earlier without actually reducing mortality. This type of bias is called lead-time bias. The lead time bias can overestimate the survival time by the early detection of a disease. 

Lead time is the time gained by screening. It is the time between diagnosis by a screening test and diagnosis by other means. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of a disease.

Lead time bias may arise when survival times are selected as endpoints in screening trials. Early diagnosis can lead to an overestimation of survival times because an early diagnosis through screening does not accurately represent delayed mortality. 

For example, a CT scan of the chest identifies a malignant tumor of the lung earlier than a traditional chest x-ray. However, early treatment does not significantly enhance overall survival in patients with lung cancer. Therefore, any apparent improvement in the 5-year survival rates of patients diagnosed through a CT scan compared to those diagnosed with an X-ray is attributed to lead-time bias. 

Other options: 

Option A: Berksonian bias arises because of the different rates of admission to hospitals for people with different diseases. It is seen in case-control studies. 

Option C: Detection bias arises in unblinded randomised trials and observational analyses when knowing the treatment assigned causes systematic differences in determining outcomes between study groups. 

Option D: Survival bias is the phenomenon by which individuals are excluded from analysis of a trait because of mortality related to the expression of that trait. For example, studying only cancer survivors ignores those who died early from cancer.

Pearl PM0361: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.



Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Pearl PM0266: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  


Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text:
8. In a randomised controlled trial, what is the order of the following steps in a sequential manner from early to late?

* Randomisation

* Manipulation

* Statistical assessment

* Follow-up
questions.solution:
In a randomised controlled trial, the order of steps in a sequential manner from early to late is Randomisation → Manipulation → Follow-up → Statistical assessment (1, 2, 4, 3). 

Experimental studies are of two types:

* Randomized controlled trials (RCT) which involve a process of random allocation

* Non-randomized trials with no strict randomization

The basic steps in conducting a RCT includes:

* Drawing up a protocol which specifies the aims and objectives of the study, criteria for selection of study and control groups and size of the sample. 

* Selecting reference and experimental populations whose cooperation is assured to avoid loses to follow-up.

* Randomization which is a statistical procedure by which the participants are allocated into study and control groups. It eliminates bias and is the heart of a control trial. 

* Manipulation or intervention by deliberate application or withdrawal of the suspected causal factor. 

* Follow-up, which implies examination of the experimental and control group at defined intervals of time in a standard manner. 

* Assessment of outcome, which is the final step of the trial in terms of positive or negative results.

questions.text: 9. A 58 year old male with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus presents with high-grade fever and cough. He is diagnosed with COVID-19 and is admitted. He dies on the 7th day of illness. As part of surveillance, his death is recorded. What type of surveillance is this?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient’s death due to a specific disease (COVID-19) is recorded as part of an existing disease surveillance system. Since the information is collected from hospitals or health facilities without active searching, it falls under passive surveillance.

Surveillance is defined as continuous analysis, interpretation, and feedback of systematically collected data. It is continuous and ongoing, whereas monitoring is more intermittent or episodic. It can be of two types: 

* Active surveillance is a system employing staff members to regularly contact health care providers or the population to seek information about health conditions (Option A). Active surveillance provides the most accurate and timely information, but it is also expensive. 

* Passive surveillance is a system by which a health jurisdiction receives reports submitted from hospitals, clinics, public health units, or other sources. Passive surveillance is a relatively inexpensive strategy to cover large areas, and it provides critical information for monitoring a community's health. However, because passive surveillance depends on people in different institutions to provide data, data quality and timeliness are difficult to control.

Other options:

Option C: Sentinel surveillance is a method of identifying the missing cases that are not on the notified cases list. It is used for supplementing routine notifications. The sentinel data collected in this type of surveillance can estimate the disease prevalence (old and new cases) in the total population. This system provides more valuable and detailed information compared to what is obtained from traditional notification systems.

Option D: Syndromic surveillance focuses on the clinical pattern and broad category of presentation, which is determined by paramedical personnel and members of the community. It is covered under the Integrated Disease Surveillance project and includes the following clinical syndromes:

* Fever

* Cough for more than 3 weeks duration

* Acute Flaccid paralysis

* Diarrhoea

* Jaundice

* Unusual events causing death or hospitalisation

These syndromes are intended to pick up all priority diseases at the level of the community.

questions.text: 10. As per population strategy, what is the recommended dietary reduction of cholesterol to prevent coronary heart disease?
questions.solution:
The recommended dietary reduction of cholesterol to prevent coronary heart disease (CHD) is to reduce below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day.

Population strategy is based on a mass approach, focusing mainly on the control of underlying causes in whole populations. This approach is based on the principle that small changes in risk factor levels in total population can achieve the biggest reduction in mortality. 

Dietary changes under the population strategy in the prevention of CHD:

* Reduction of the fat intake to 20–30% of total energy intake

* Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake

* A reduction of dietary cholesterol to below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day

* Increase in the complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and legumes)

* Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5g daily or less

questions.text: 11. A new community based health initiative is designed to reduce neonatal sepsis. In a community, 20 PHCs follow standard care and 20 are designated to implement the initiative. What type of study design is this?
questions.solution:
The given scenario described the study design of a cluster randomised controlled trial.

This is a cluster randomised controlled trial because the unit of allocation in this study is not the individual patient but the primary health centre (PHC), which acts as a cluster. Instead of randomly assigning each newborn or mother individually, the researchers assign entire PHCs to either the intervention (new community-based initiative to reduce neonatal sepsis) or the control (standard care) group.

Other options:

Option A: This is not a quasi-experimental study because in quasi-experimental designs there is no true random allocation of participants or groups. In the given scenario, the 20 PHCs implementing the intervention and the 20 PHCs following standard care are assigned in a way that strongly suggests randomisation at the cluster level, which rules out a quasi-experimental approach.

Option C: This is not a case-control study because it doesn’t start with outcomes and look back for exposures. Instead, it begins with an intervention and follows forward.

Option D: This is not a cross-sectional study because it is not based on a single examination of a cross-section of the population at one point in time, but it involves an intervention with follow-up over time.

Pearl PM1146: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

* In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.

* Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.



2. Stratified random sampling

* In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.

* For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.



3. Cluster sampling

* In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.

* In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.

* This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.

* This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.

* Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.

* Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.



4. Systematic random sampling

* In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.

* For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: 12. A 3-year old girl presented with difficulty in walking and bowing of legs. She was undernourished and had minimal exposure to the sun. Which programme deals with nutritional deficiency in children below 6 years of age?
questions.solution:
For children below 6 years of age, the programme that deals with nutritional deficiency is the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS).

The scenario in this case points toward rickets due to Vitamin D deficiency which presents as difficulty in walking and bowing of legs with minimal sun exposure and undernutrition.

Integrated child development services was launched in October, 1975, with focus on early childhood services, which consist of supplementary nutrition, immunisation, health check-up, medical referral services, nutrition and health education for women and non-formal education of children upto the age of 6 years. 

The main objectives of the ICDS scheme are:

* Improve the health and nutritional status of children between 0–6 years, pregnant and lactating mothers 

* Reduction in the incidence of their mortality and school dropout 

* Provision of a firm foundation for the proper psychological, physical and social development of the child 

* Enhancement of the maternal education and capacity to look after her health and nutrition and that of her family

* Effective coordination of the policy and implementation among various departments and programmes aimed to promote child development

Other options: 

Option B: Anaemia Mukt Bharat targets iron deficiency anaemia mainly through iron–folic acid supplementation, deworming, and awareness activities. It covers children of 6–59 months, school-going children, adolescents, and women of reproductive age including pregnant and lactating women. Since it focuses on anaemia and multiple age groups, it doesn’t address this child’s condition.

Option C: There is no standalone programme by the name “National Nutritional Deficiency Control Programme.” Instead, this term is sometimes used as an umbrella description for multiple initiatives aimed at controlling specific deficiencies like iodine, vitamin A, and anaemia. It is not a single, targeted scheme for children under six, but rather a collection of separate interventions across age groups. It does not specifically address the child’s rickets or provide comprehensive early childhood nutrition support.

Option D: Mid-Day Meal Scheme, now known as PM Poshan Scheme, provides nutritious meals to improve the nutritional status of children studying in classes I-VIII in eligible schools. It aims to improve school attendance and nutrition, but does not cover pre-school children below six years, so it’s not relevant for the 3-year-old child in this case.

Pearl PM2152: Integrated child development services (ICDS)

Integrated child development services (ICDS): Package of services provided include:

Beneficiary Services
Pregnant women
  • Health check up
  • Tetanus immunization
  • Supplementary nutrition
  • Nutrition and health education
Nursing mothers
  • Health check up
  • Supplementary nutrition
  • Nutrition and health education
Other women 15-45 years
  • Nutrition and health education
Children <3 years
  • Supplementary nutrition
  • Immunization
  • Health check up
  • Referral services
Children 3-6 years of age
  • Supplementary nutrition
  • Immunization
  • Health check up
  • Referral services
  • Non formal education  
Adolescent girls 11 -18 years
  • Nutrition programme for adolescent girls
  • Kishori shakti yojana
  • Nutrition and  heath education


The logo of the ICDS is given below:

questions.text: 13. A city experiences a chemical plant leak and toxic fumes are released into the atmosphere. What is your immediate recommendation to the local residents?

choices.text: Seal cracks and close all windows and doors

questions.solution:
In a chemical plant leak where toxic fumes are released into the atmosphere, the safest immediate step before evacuation orders is to prevent the toxic fumes from entering by sealing cracks and closing all windows and doors.

In the event of a toxic gas leak, the following measures are to be taken:

1. Before the emergency:

* Find out about evacuation plans and facilities

* Familiarize yourself with the alarm signals used in case of emergency

* Equip doors and windows with the tightest possible fastenings

* Prepare family emergency kits

2. During the emergency:

* Do not use the telephone; leave lines free for rescue services (Option A)

* Listen to the messages given by radio and other media. Carry out the instructions transmitted by radio or loudspeaker

* Close doors and windows (Option C)

* Stop up air intakes

* Seal any cracks or gaps around windows and doors with adhesive tape

* Organize a reserve of water (by filling wash basins, baths, etc.)

* Turn off ventilators and air conditioners

3. After the emergency:

* Comply with the authorities’ instructions and do not go out until there is no longer any risk (Option B)

* Carry out necessary decontamination measures

* Following these steps helps to minimize exposure to harmful gases, maintain safety indoors, and ensure a safe return to normal conditions once the danger has passed

questions.text: 14. A 20 year old man from Chittoor, Andhra Pradesh presented with weakness in limbs and outward bowing of legs. His diet consisted of jowar roti and rice. He is diagnosed with osteoporosis. Which of the following interventions will you not do?

choices.text: Addition of alum and lime in drinking water
Provision of running surface water for drinking

questions.solution:
The intervention you will not do is fluoride supplementation.

The presentation of weakness in limbs, outward bowing of legs with a location in Chittoor, which is a fluorosis-endemic area, and osteoporosis-like bone changes points towards skeletal fluorosis due to excess fluoride in drinking water. A new form of flurosis characterised by genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limbs has been reported in some districts of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu. It is observed among people whose staple is sorghum (jowar) since a diet based on sorghum promotes higher retention of ingested fluoride than do diets based on rice. In such cases, the goal is to reduce fluoride intake, not supplement it.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic to certain parts of India like Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana (Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu.  Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake.

* Dental fluorosis (1.5mg/L): Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It causes mottling of dental enamel. The appearance of chalky-white, and dull patches on the teeth in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and then brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance in severe cases. Mottling is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects permanent teeth during its period of formation.

* Skeletal fluorosis (3-6mg/L): Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, and fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone. These are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.

* Crippling fluorosis (>10mg/L): Can lead to permanent disability.

* Genu valgum with osteoporosis of the lower limbs in people whose staple is sorghum (jowar). It has been seen that diets based on sorghum promoted a higher retention of ingested fluoride than diets based on rice. 

The given image shows skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification):



Interventions for Fluorosis:

* Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content of 0.5 to 0.8 mg/L (Option C). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources (Option D).

* The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur, developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 

* Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.

* The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age.

The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water, which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration (Option B). The image given below depicts the Nalgonda technique:

questions.text: 15. A medical college is organising a 'health mela' for the community. A group of students are deputed to a stall to show the 'Nalgonda technique' related to water. A student is sent to the store room to get two chemicals required for the demonstration of this technique. The following image shows the chemicals that she sees in the store room labelled A,B,C and D. Which two chemicals does she take?
questions.solution:
Nalgonda technique is a method used for defluoridation of water, and it requires alum and lime (Image 1 and 4).

Nalgonda technique was developed by the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment. The process used for the defluoridation of water involves the addition of lime and alum followed by, flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration. This process can be used for domestic and community water supplies.

The image given below depicts the Nalgonda technique:



Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic to certain parts of India like Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana (Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu.  Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake.

* Dental fluorosis (1.5mg/L): Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It causes mottling of dental enamel. The appearance of chalky-white, and dull patches on the teeth in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and then brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance in severe cases. Mottling is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects permanent teeth during its period of formation.

* Skeletal fluorosis (3-6mg/L): Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. 

* Crippling fluorosis (>10mg/L): Can lead to permanent disability.

* Genu valgum: Characterised by genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limbs and observed among people whose staple is sorghum (jowar). It is a new form of fluorosis reported in some districts of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu. 

The given image shows skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification):



Interventions for Fluorosis:

* Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.

* The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur, developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique.

* Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.

* The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age.

questions.text: 16. Which of the following is defined as "measuring the degree to which objectives and targets are met and the quality of the results obtained"?
questions.solution:
Evaluation is defined as measuring the degree to which objectives and targets are met and the quality of the results obtained, as per the WHO Expert Committee on National Health Planning in Developing Countries. 

The purpose of evaluation is to assess the achievement of the objectives of a programme, its adequacy and efficiency. It measures the productivity of available resources in achieving clearly defined objectives. It measures how much output or cost-effectiveness is achieved. 

Other options:

Option A: Monitoring is the day-to-day follow-up of activities during their implementation. It is a continuous process of observing, recording and reporting on the activities of the organisation or project. It keeps track of the course activities and identifies deviations. 

Option B: Planning is the formulation of a plan. A plan is the blueprint for taking action in order to achieve the goal. The planning cycle includes:



Option D: Supervision is a systematic activity for increasing the efficiency of health workers through direct contacts. It is an extension of training that serves to increase the knowledge, perfect the skills, improve the attitudes and strengthen the motivation of involved health personnel.

questions.text: 17. A city has 70,00,000 urban population, 30% of which live in slums. How many U-PHCs are required for the slum population according to NUHM norms?
questions.solution:
42 U-PHCs are required for the slum population according to NUHM norms.

The total urban population of the city is 70,00,000, out of which 30% live in slums. This means the slum population is 30/100 x 70,00,000 = 21,00,000.

According to National Urban Health Mission, one Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC) is required for every 50,000 people living in slum and vulnerable areas. By dividing 21,00,000 by 50,000, we get 42, which means the city would require 42 U-PHCs to adequately cover its slum population.

Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC) are functional for a population of approximately 50,000 and may be located preferably within a slum or near a slum within half a kilometer radius. At the U-PHC level services provided will include OPD (consultation), basic laboratory diagnosis, drug/contraceptive dispensing, apart from distribution of health education material, delivering RCH services and counselling for all communicable and non-communicable diseases. In order to ensure access to the urban slum population at convenient timings, the U-PHC provide services from 12 noon to 8 pm.

The urban health care facilities under the National Urban Health Mission are shown in the image below:



Pearl PM0158: Primary Health Centres-PHC

* HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas

* Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000

* Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s Bed distribution: 

HWC-PHC HWC-UPHC 24X7 HWC-PHC/UPHC
Essential: 2 beds Essential: 2 daycare beds Essential: 6 beds
Desirable: +4 beds Desirable: +4 daycare beds Desirable: +4 beds


Note: The desirable will be over and above the essential beds. The twelve packages envisaged under Comprehensive Primary Healthcare services (CPHC): 

* Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth 

* Neonatal and Infant Health Care Services

* Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services

* Family Planning, Contraceptive Services, and other Reproductive Health Care Services

* Management of Communicable Diseases: National Health Programmes

* General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments

* Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-communicable Diseases

* Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problems

* Basic Oral Health Care

* Elderly and Palliative Health Care Services

* Emergency Medical Services including Burns and Trauma

* Screening and Basic Management of Mental Health Ailments.

IPHS 2022 normal for manpower at PHC:

Essential manpower for:

1) PHC: 12   2) UPHC: 16   3) Polyclinic: 22   4) 24x7 PHC: 23   5) 24X7 UPHC: 27
